questions.text: ​​​​​ In a child undergoing cataract surgery, which of the following is added to the irrigating solution to prevent postoperative inflammatory membrane formation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heparin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Adrenaline (Epinephrine) is often added to local anesthetic solutions to constrict blood vessels, thereby reducing bleeding and prolonging the duration of anesthesia . While it may help in maintaining pupil dilation during surgery , it is not primarily used for controlling postoperative inflammation.
  • • Option A. Adrenaline (Epinephrine)
  • • added
  • • local anesthetic solutions
  • • constrict blood vessels,
  • • reducing bleeding
  • • prolonging
  • • duration
  • • anesthesia
  • • maintaining pupil dilation
  • • surgery
  • • Option B. Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that causes dilation of the pupil and paralysis of accommodation . It is not typically used in the irrigating solution during cataract surgery, and its primary role is not in controlling postoperative inflammation.
  • • Option B. Atropine
  • • muscarinic antagonist
  • • dilation
  • • pupil
  • • paralysis
  • • accommodation
  • • Option D. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects . While it is commonly used in ophthalmology for controlling inflammation , it is typically administered as an eye drop or injection , not in the irrigating solution during surgery.
  • • Option D. Dexamethasone
  • • corticosteroid
  • • anti-inflammatory
  • • immunosuppressive effects
  • • ophthalmology
  • • controlling inflammation
  • • typically administered
  • • eye drop
  • • injection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heparin is added to the irrigating solution during pediatric cataract surgery to prevent the formation of postoperative inflammatory membranes .
  • ➤ Heparin
  • ➤ irrigating solution
  • ➤ pediatric cataract
  • ➤ surgery
  • ➤ prevent
  • ➤ formation
  • ➤ postoperative inflammatory membranes
  • ➤ Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE PAGE 158
  • ➤ Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE PAGE 158

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive vision loss in both eyes over the past few months. Upon examination, a swollen, bulging lens with increased lens thickness is observed. The diagnosis of intumescent cataract is made. What is the diameter of a normal adult crystalline lens?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 9 – 11 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diameter of the lens :
  • • Diameter
  • • lens
  • • At Birth = 6.5 mm Adult = 9 to 11 mm
  • • At Birth = 6.5 mm
  • • Adult = 9 to 11 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diameter if normal crystalline lens is 9-11 mm .
  • ➤ diameter
  • ➤ 9-11 mm
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 110/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eyeball /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 110/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eyeball /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmia is currently receiving treatment with Amiodarone. The patient complains of defective vision, prompting an ophthalmic evaluation. Given the patient's medication history, what is the probable form of cataract that may be observed in this individual?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior Subcapsular Cataract

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Posterior Polar Cataract is located at the posterior pole of the lens and is often due to congenital posterior capsular dehiscence . It has a whirl like appearance .
  • • Option B. Posterior Polar Cataract
  • • posterior pole
  • • lens
  • • congenital posterior capsular dehiscence
  • • whirl like appearance
  • • Option C. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC) forms under the posterior capsule of the lens . This type of cataract is associated with several factors , including long-term use of corticosteroids , radiation , and intraocular inflammation .
  • • Option C. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC)
  • • posterior capsule
  • • lens
  • • cataract
  • • several factors
  • • long-term use
  • • corticosteroids
  • • radiation
  • • intraocular inflammation
  • • It has a “bread crump” appearance
  • • “bread crump” appearance
  • • Option D. Anterior Polar Cataract forms at the front pole of the lens and is often congenital . It's not typically associated with medication use like Amiodarone.
  • • Option D. Anterior Polar Cataract
  • • front pole
  • • lens
  • • congenital

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amiodarone is associated with anterior subcapsular cataract .
  • ➤ Amiodarone
  • ➤ anterior subcapsular cataract
  • ➤ Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22 nd Edition Page 367
  • ➤ Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22 nd Edition Page 367

questions.text: During development of the eyeball, the neural plate becomes thickened & depressed to form which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Optic Sulcus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. The optic vesicle is formed when the neural plate becomes thickened and depressed , leading to the formation of the optic sulcus , which then buds out to form the optic vesicle.
  • • Option B.
  • • optic vesicle
  • • neural plate
  • • thickened
  • • depressed
  • • formation
  • • optic sulcus
  • • Option C. The optic stalk is the structure that connects the developing optic vesicle to the brain . As the optic vesicle grows out to form the eye , the connecting stalk forms the optic nerve .
  • • Option C.
  • • optic stalk
  • • connects
  • • developing optic vesicle
  • • brain
  • • optic vesicle
  • • form
  • • eye
  • • connecting stalk
  • • optic nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understand that during the development of the eyeball , the neural plate becomes thickened and depressed to form the optic sulcus .
  • ➤ development
  • ➤ eyeball
  • ➤ neural plate
  • ➤ thickened
  • ➤ depressed
  • ➤ form
  • ➤ optic sulcus
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 9/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6 th Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 9/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6 th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: For a patient scheduled for cataract surgery, a pharmacological agent was administered before the procedure to prevent intraoperative miosis. This drug, commonly used in such cases, helps maintain pupil dilation during surgery, facilitating optimal visualization of the surgical field. Identify the drug that was administered.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 0.03% Flurbiprofen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 1% Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that causes pupil dilation ( mydriasis ) and paralysis of accommodation ( cycloplegia ).
  • • Option A. 1% Atropine
  • • muscarinic antagonist
  • • pupil dilation
  • • mydriasis
  • • paralysis
  • • accommodation
  • • cycloplegia
  • • Option C. 10% Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist that induces mydriasis without cycloplegia . It is often used in cataract surgery to maintain pupil dilation . Its rapid onset and effectiveness in dilating the pupil make it a common choice for this purpose.
  • • Option C. 10% Phenylephrine
  • • alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist
  • • induces mydriasis
  • • without cycloplegia
  • • cataract surgery
  • • maintain pupil dilation
  • • rapid onset
  • • effectiveness
  • • dilating
  • • pupil
  • • common choice
  • • Option D. 0.5% Proparacaine is a topical anesthetic used in ophthalmology to anesthetise the cornea .
  • • Option D. 0.5% Proparacaine
  • • topical anesthetic
  • • ophthalmology
  • • anesthetise
  • • cornea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The drug administered to prevent intraoperative miosis during cataract surgery is 0.03% Flurbiprofen, an NSAID , as it specifically targets the prevention of miosis during surgical procedures . While phenylephrine is also a mydriatic agent , its primary role is not the prevention of miosis but rather the induction of mydriasis . Flurbiprofen's role in inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis directly counteracts the factors that cause miosis during surgery.
  • ➤ drug administered
  • ➤ prevent intraoperative miosis
  • ➤ cataract surgery
  • ➤ 0.03% Flurbiprofen, an NSAID
  • ➤ targets
  • ➤ prevention
  • ➤ miosis
  • ➤ surgical procedures
  • ➤ phenylephrine
  • ➤ mydriatic agent
  • ➤ induction
  • ➤ mydriasis
  • ➤ Flurbiprofen's role
  • ➤ inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
  • ➤ counteracts
  • ➤ cause miosis
  • ➤ surgery.
  • ➤ Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22 nd Edition Page 155
  • ➤ Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22 nd Edition Page 155

questions.text: A patient posted for cataract surgery has a corneal endothelial cell count of 1250 cells/mm 2 . Which of the following ophthalmic visco-surgical devices would the surgeon prefer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sodium Hyaluronate + Chondroitin Sulphate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sodium Hyaluronate is a commonly used cohesive OVD in cataract surgery . It is effective in maintaining space and protecting the cornea .
  • • Option A.
  • • cohesive OVD
  • • cataract surgery
  • • effective
  • • maintaining space
  • • protecting
  • • cornea
  • • Option B. Hydroxypropyl Methylcellulose (HPMC) is a less cohesive , more dispersive OVD compared to sodium hyaluronate .
  • • Option B.
  • • less cohesive
  • • more dispersive
  • • sodium hyaluronate
  • • Option D. Keratan Sulphate is not commonly used as an OVD in cataract surgery. It's more known for its presence in the corneal stroma , but it doesn't have the viscoelastic properties required for an OVD.
  • • Option D.
  • • presence
  • • corneal stroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the patient's low endothelial cell count , the surgeon would prefer Sodium Hyaluronate + Chondroitin Sulphate . This combination provides both the space-maintaining benefits of sodium hyaluronate (cohesive) and the endothelial protective properties of chondroitin sulphate (dispersive) , making it ideal for cases where the corneal endothelium is compromised .
  • ➤ low endothelial cell count
  • ➤ Sodium Hyaluronate + Chondroitin Sulphate
  • ➤ both
  • ➤ space-maintaining benefits
  • ➤ sodium hyaluronate (cohesive)
  • ➤ endothelial protective properties
  • ➤ chondroitin sulphate (dispersive)
  • ➤ corneal endothelium
  • ➤ compromised
  • ➤ Endothelial cell protection is mainly a function of dispersive OVD .
  • ➤ function
  • ➤ dispersive OVD
  • ➤ Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE PAGE 159
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE PAGE 159

questions.text: Which component of the eye has the maximum refractive index?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Crystalline Lens

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cornea – RI of cornea is 1.376
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Aqueous Humor – RI of aqueous is 1.336
  • • Option B.
  • • Option D. Vitreous Humor – RI of vitreous is 1.336
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crystalline lens has the maximum refractive in the eye .
  • ➤ maximum refractive

questions.text: A 65-year-old man came to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of gradually increasing blurring of vision in both his eyes since 1 year. After examination, he was diagnosed with bilateral mature senile cataract and was explained how his lenses had lost their transparency leading to blurring of vision. Factors that play significant role in maintaining the outstanding clarity of normal lens are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vascularity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The lens is covered by a single layer of epithelial cells on its anterior surface . These cells are essential for lens growth and transparency . They help regulate water and ion balance in the lens and produce lens fibers , which are crucial for maintaining lens clarity .
  • • Option A.
  • • covered
  • • single layer
  • • epithelial cells
  • • anterior surface
  • • essential
  • • lens growth
  • • transparency
  • • regulate water
  • • ion balance
  • • lens
  • • lens fibers
  • • maintaining lens clarity
  • • Option B. Lens has natural auto oxidation mechanism .
  • • Option B.
  • • natural auto oxidation mechanism
  • • Option D. The lens contains ion channels and pumps that help maintain its dehydration and precise ion balance , which are essential for lens transparency . Disruption in this pump mechanism can lead to cataract formation .
  • • Option D.
  • • ion channels
  • • pumps
  • • dehydration
  • • precise ion balance
  • • lens transparency
  • • Disruption
  • • pump mechanism
  • • cataract formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lens is an avascular structure , meaning it lacks blood vessels . This avascularity is crucial for its transparency . If the lens were vascularized , the blood vessels would interfere with light transmission and clarity .
  • ➤ avascular structure
  • ➤ lacks blood vessels
  • ➤ avascularity
  • ➤ transparency
  • ➤ vascularized
  • ➤ interfere
  • ➤ light transmission
  • ➤ clarity
  • ➤ Ref: 127/ Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd Edition
  • ➤ Ref: 127/ Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3 rd Edition

questions.text: The Percentage Distribution of Water & Proteins in Crystalline Lens respectively, is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 65%, 35%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Main constituents of the lens are Water ( 65% ) & Proteins ( 35% ).
  • ➤ Water
  • ➤ 65%
  • ➤ Proteins
  • ➤ 35%
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 118/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 118/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: In the lens, what is/are the pathway(s) involved in the metabolism of glucose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle ) is a key metabolic pathway that generates energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins . However, in the lens , the Krebs cycle plays a minimal role because the lens operates in a relatively hypoxic environment and relies more on anaerobic glycolysis for its energy requirements .
  • • Option A.
  • • citric acid cycle
  • • TCA cycle
  • • metabolic pathway
  • • generates energy
  • • oxidation
  • • acetyl-CoA
  • • carbohydrates, fats,
  • • proteins
  • • lens
  • • Krebs cycle
  • • minimal role
  • • operates
  • • relatively hypoxic environment
  • • relies
  • • anaerobic glycolysis
  • • energy requirements
  • • Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway) , also known as the pentose phosphate pathway , is an important metabolic pathway in the lens . It provides the lens with NADPH , which is crucial for maintaining reduced glutathione levels . Reduced glutathione is vital for protecting the lens against oxidative stress , thus helping maintain its transparency and preventing cataract formation .
  • • Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway)
  • • pentose phosphate pathway
  • • metabolic pathway
  • • lens
  • • NADPH
  • • crucial
  • • reduced glutathione levels
  • • Reduced glutathione
  • • protecting
  • • against oxidative stress
  • • maintain
  • • transparency
  • • preventing cataract formation
  • • Option C. Sorbitol Pathway , also known as the polyol pathway , involves the conversion of glucose to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase . In the lens, this pathway becomes particularly active in hyperglycemic conditions , such as in diabetes , and can lead to the accumulation of sorbitol . Excessive accumulation of sorbitol can cause osmotic stress , leading to lens swelling , opacification , and cataract formation .
  • • Option C. Sorbitol Pathway
  • • polyol pathway
  • • conversion
  • • glucose
  • • sorbitol
  • • enzyme aldose reductase
  • • active
  • • hyperglycemic conditions
  • • diabetes
  • • lead
  • • accumulation
  • • sorbitol
  • • Excessive accumulation
  • • osmotic stress
  • • lens swelling
  • • opacification
  • • cataract formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose metabolism in the lens is through Krebs cycle , HMP pathway and Sorbitol pathway .
  • ➤ Glucose metabolism
  • ➤ Krebs cycle
  • ➤ HMP pathway
  • ➤ Sorbitol pathway
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 123/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 123/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which enzyme is implicated in Classic Galactosaemic, an inborn error of Galactose Metabolism that leads to the development of Cataracts in Infants?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GALPUT (Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyltransferase)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Galactokinase deficiency is another form of galactosemia , known as galactokinase deficiency galactosemia .
  • • Option B.
  • • galactosemia
  • • galactokinase deficiency galactosemia
  • • Option C. Aldose Reductase is involved in the polyol pathway , where it reduces glucose to sorbitol . While important in the context of diabetes-related cataract formation , it is not the enzyme implicated in classic galactosemia.
  • • Option C. Aldose Reductase
  • • polyol pathway
  • • reduces glucose
  • • sorbitol
  • • diabetes-related cataract formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GALPUT (Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase) D eficiency leads to classic Galactosemia , which is associated with the development of cataracts in infants .
  • ➤ GALPUT (Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase) D
  • ➤ eficiency
  • ➤ classic Galactosemia
  • ➤ cataracts
  • ➤ infants
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 134/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 134/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Absence of which of the following enzymes in the sorbitol pathway leads to accumulation of excess sugar?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aldose Reductase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hexokinase catalyzes the first step in glycolysis , the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate . While it's important in glucose metabolism, it is not directly involved in the sorbitol pathway. Hexokinase deficiency would affect glycolysis but not specifically lead to the accumulation of excess sugar in the sorbitol pathway.
  • • Option B. Hexokinase
  • • glycolysis
  • • glucose-6-phosphate
  • • Hexokinase deficiency
  • • affect glycolysis
  • • Option C. Aldose Reductase catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol , the first step in the sorbitol pathway . However, a deficiency in aldose reductase would actually lead to less sorbitol being produced from glucose , not more.
  • • Option C. Aldose Reductase
  • • reduction
  • • glucose
  • • sorbitol
  • • sorbitol pathway
  • • deficiency
  • • aldose reductase
  • • lead
  • • less sorbitol
  • • glucose
  • • Option D.Galactokinase is involved in galactose metabolism , not the sorbitol pathway. It catalyzes the phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate . Galactokinase deficiency leads to a different type of galactosemia but would not directly cause the accumulation of sorbitol.
  • • Option D.Galactokinase
  • • galactose metabolism
  • • phosphorylation
  • • galactose
  • • galactose-1-phosphate
  • • Galactokinase deficiency
  • • galactosemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absence or deficiency of Sorbitol Dehydrogenase in the sorbitol pathway leads to the accumulation of sorbitol , as it cannot be efficiently converted to fructose, leading to osmotic stress in cells and formation of cataract.
  • ➤ absence
  • ➤ deficiency
  • ➤ Sorbitol Dehydrogenase
  • ➤ sorbitol pathway
  • ➤ leads
  • ➤ accumulation
  • ➤ sorbitol
  • ➤ osmotic stress
  • ➤ cells
  • ➤ formation
  • ➤ cataract.
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Where does Glycolysis take place?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cytosol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. The nucleus is the control center of the cell where DNA is stored and replicated , but it is not involved in glycolysis.
  • • Option B.
  • • control center
  • • cell
  • • DNA
  • • stored
  • • replicated
  • • Option C. Although mitochondria are often referred to as the powerhouse of the cell and are the site of the citric acid cycle ( Krebs cycle ) and oxidative phosphorylation , they are not the site of glycolysis.
  • • Option C.
  • • powerhouse
  • • cell
  • • site
  • • citric acid cycle
  • • Krebs cycle
  • • oxidative phosphorylation
  • • Option D. Lysosomes are involved in breaking down waste materials and cellular debris . They are not the site of glycolysis.
  • • Option D.
  • • breaking down waste materials
  • • cellular debris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycolysis takes place in the Cytosol .
  • ➤ Glycolysis
  • ➤ Cytosol
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 41/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 41/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What can be prevented by inhibiting Aldol Reductase in Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diabetic Cataract

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. While diabetic nephropathy is a major complication of diabetes , the role of aldose reductase in its development is less direct compared to its role in cataracts.
  • • Option B.
  • • diabetic nephropathy
  • • major complication
  • • diabetes
  • • aldose reductase
  • • development
  • • less direct compared
  • • role
  • • Option C. Diabetic Neuropathy is also a complication where aldose reductase plays a role. Increased activity of the polyol pathway in nerve cells can lead to osmotic and oxidative stress , contributing to nerve damage . Inhibiting aldose reductase can therefore potentially help in preventing or slowing the progression of diabetic neuropathy .
  • • Option C. Diabetic Neuropathy
  • • aldose reductase
  • • Increased activity
  • • polyol pathway
  • • nerve cells
  • • osmotic
  • • oxidative stress
  • • nerve damage
  • • Inhibiting aldose reductase
  • • potentially
  • • preventing
  • • slowing
  • • progression
  • • diabetic neuropathy
  • • Option D. Deafness : While diabetes can lead to a range of complications , there is no direct evidence linking aldose reductase activity to diabetes-related deafness. Deafness in diabetic patients is more commonly associated with other factors such as microvascular complications and neuropathies .
  • • Option D. Deafness
  • • range of complications
  • • microvascular complications
  • • neuropathies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most direct and well-established effect of inhibiting aldose reductase in the context of diabetes is the prevention of Diabetic Cataract
  • ➤ most direct
  • ➤ well-established
  • ➤ effect
  • ➤ inhibiting aldose reductase
  • ➤ context
  • ➤ diabetes
  • ➤ Diabetic Cataract
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3 rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A patient evaluated for cataract surgery also had residual cylinder power correction needed. What would be the procedure of choice to address both the situations?
questions.correct_answer: B. Phacoemulsification with Toric IOLS Implantation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phacomeulsification with Toric IOLS implantation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. TORIC ICL (Implantable Collamer Lens) Implantation are used to correct refractive errors , including myopia and astigmatism . However, they are not typically used for cataract surgery. ICLs are implanted in addition to the natural lens and are more commonly used in refractive surgery for patients without cataracts .
  • • Option A. TORIC ICL (Implantable Collamer Lens) Implantation
  • • correct refractive errors
  • • myopia
  • • astigmatism
  • • implanted
  • • natural lens
  • • refractive surgery
  • • without cataracts
  • • Option C. While phacoemulsification with the implantation of a multifocal IOL is an effective treatment for cataracts and can provide a range of vision (near to far), multifocal IOLs do not specifically correct astigmatism. They are more focused on reducing the need for reading glasses or bifocals post-surgery .
  • • Option C.
  • • effective treatment
  • • cataracts
  • • range of vision
  • • more focused
  • • reducing
  • • need
  • • reading glasses
  • • bifocals post-surgery
  • • Option D. MSICS (Manual Small Incision Cataract Surgery) is an effective method for cataract removal , especially in developing countries or in cases where phacoemulsification equipment is not available . However, this procedure does not inherently correct astigmatism.
  • • Option D. MSICS (Manual Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
  • • effective method
  • • cataract removal
  • • phacoemulsification equipment
  • • not available

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate choice for a patient needing both cataract surgery and astigmatism correction is Phacoemulsification with Toric IOLs Implantation . This option directly addresses the cataract through phacoemulsification and corrects astigmatism with the implantation of a toric IOL .
  • ➤ most appropriate choice
  • ➤ cataract surgery
  • ➤ astigmatism correction
  • ➤ Phacoemulsification with Toric IOLs Implantation
  • ➤ directly addresses
  • ➤ cataract
  • ➤ phacoemulsification
  • ➤ corrects astigmatism
  • ➤ implantation
  • ➤ toric IOL
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 310/ Intraocular Lenses/ Theory & Practise of Optics of Refraction
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 310/ Intraocular Lenses/ Theory & Practise of Optics of Refraction

questions.text: A cataract surgeon noticed zonular dehiscence in a patient preoperatively of less than 2 clock hours. What precaution can be taken during surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) Insertion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Iris hooks are used to mechanically dilate the pupil in cases where pharmacological dilation is insufficient . While they provide better visualization during surgery , they do not address zonular dehiscence or the stability of the lens capsule.
  • • Option A.
  • • mechanically dilate
  • • pupil
  • • pharmacological dilation
  • • insufficient
  • • better visualization
  • • surgery
  • • Option B. Multifocal IOLs provide a range of vision post-cataract surgery but have no role in managing zonular dehiscence. The choice of IOL doesn't directly impact the surgical approach to zonular weakness.
  • • Option B.
  • • range of
  • • vision
  • • post-cataract surgery
  • • Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis) is a refractive surgery procedure for correcting vision issues like myopia , hyperopia , and astigmatism . It is unrelated to the management of zonular dehiscence in cataract surgery.
  • • Option C.
  • • refractive surgery procedure
  • • correcting vision issues
  • • myopia
  • • hyperopia
  • • astigmatism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the scenario of zonular dehiscence of less than 2 clock hours , the precaution that can be taken during cataract surgery is - Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) insertion . This approach helps to manage the weakened zonular support effectively , ensuring a safer surgical procedure and better outcomes .
  • ➤ zonular dehiscence
  • ➤ less than 2 clock hours
  • ➤ precaution
  • ➤ during cataract surgery
  • ➤ - Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) insertion
  • ➤ manage
  • ➤ weakened zonular support
  • ➤ effectively
  • ➤ safer surgical procedure
  • ➤ better outcomes
  • ➤ Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Capsular_Support_Devices
  • ➤ Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Capsular_Support_Devices

questions.text: In FLACS (Femto Laser Assisted Cataract Surgery), what is the Femto Laser used for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Anterior Capsulotomy: The femtosecond laser is used to create a precise , circular incision in the anterior capsule of the lens , which is a critical step for accessing and removing the cataract . This laser-assisted capsulotomy is known for its precision and reproducibility compared to the manual technique .
  • • Option A.
  • • precise
  • • circular incision
  • • anterior capsule
  • • lens
  • • critical step
  • • accessing
  • • removing
  • • cataract
  • • laser-assisted capsulotomy
  • • precision
  • • reproducibility
  • • manual technique
  • • Option B. Arcuate Keratotomies: The femtosecond laser can also be used to perform arcuate keratotomies , which are precise incisions in the cornea to correct pre-existing astigmatism . This enhances the refractive outcomes of cataract surgery .
  • • Option B.
  • • perform arcuate keratotomies
  • • precise incisions
  • • cornea
  • • correct pre-existing astigmatism
  • • enhances
  • • refractive outcomes
  • • cataract surgery
  • • Option C. Nuclear Fragmentation: The femtosecond laser can pre-fragment the cataractous lens (nucleus) which can reduce the amount of ultrasound energy ( phacoemulsification ) needed to subsequently break up and remove the lens material , potentially leading to less trauma to the eye .
  • • Option C.
  • • pre-fragment
  • • cataractous lens (nucleus)
  • • reduce
  • • amount
  • • ultrasound energy
  • • phacoemulsification
  • • subsequently break up
  • • remove
  • • lens material
  • • potentially leading
  • • less trauma
  • • eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The femtosecond laser in FLACS is a versatile tool that enhances the precision, safety , and refractive outcomes of cataract surgery by assisting in multiple key steps of the procedure .
  • ➤ versatile tool
  • ➤ enhances
  • ➤ precision, safety
  • ➤ refractive outcomes
  • ➤ cataract surgery
  • ➤ assisting
  • ➤ multiple key steps
  • ➤ procedure
  • ➤ Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Femtosecond_Cataract_Surgery
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://eyewiki.aao.org/Femtosecond_Cataract_Surgery

questions.text: In case of posterior capsular rupture, where are the GLUED IOLs placed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Behind the Iris

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. In the Anterior Chamber IOLs are placed in front of the iris . This option is generally considered when there is inadequate support in the posterior chamber , but it's less favored due to potential complications like corneal endothelial damage and secondary glaucoma .
  • • Option A. In the Anterior Chamber
  • • IOLs
  • • front
  • • iris
  • • inadequate support
  • • posterior chamber
  • • less favored
  • • potential complications
  • • corneal endothelial damage
  • • secondary glaucoma
  • • Option B. Attached to Iris-fixated IOLs are another option where the lens is attached to the iris . This can be done in cases where there is insufficient capsular support , but it requires sufficient structural integrity of the iris and careful consideration of potential complications , such as iris chafing .
  • • Option B. Attached to Iris-fixated IOLs
  • • lens
  • • attached
  • • iris
  • • insufficient capsular support
  • • requires sufficient
  • • structural integrity
  • • potential complications
  • • iris chafing
  • • Option D. None of the Above : This option is incorrect given that one of the above choices accurately describes the placement of glued IOLs .
  • • Option D. None of the Above
  • • incorrect
  • • accurately
  • • placement
  • • glued IOLs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understand that in cases of posterior capsular rupture , glued intraocular lenses (IOLs) are typically placed in the sulcus , behind the iris , using a technique that secures the IOL to the sclera with fibrin glue for stable fixation .
  • ➤ posterior capsular rupture
  • ➤ glued intraocular lenses (IOLs)
  • ➤ sulcus
  • ➤ behind
  • ➤ iris
  • ➤ secures
  • ➤ IOL
  • ➤ sclera
  • ➤ fibrin glue
  • ➤ stable fixation
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.aao.org/education/current-insight/glued-iol-technique
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://www.aao.org/education/current-insight/glued-iol-technique

questions.text: Which of the following IOLs is used to correct both distant & near vision?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of them.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IOLs used for correcting both distant & near vision together include:
  • ➤ both distant
  • ➤ near vision
  • ➤ Trifocal iols Bifocal IOLs or Multifocal IOLs Diffractive iols Accommodative IOLs Extended Depth of Focus IOL.
  • ➤ Trifocal iols
  • ➤ Bifocal IOLs or Multifocal IOLs
  • ➤ Diffractive iols
  • ➤ Accommodative IOLs
  • ➤ Extended Depth of Focus IOL.
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 310/ Theory & Practise of Optics & Refraction/ 4 th Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 310/ Theory & Practise of Optics & Refraction/ 4 th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Identify the type of IOL.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Multifocal IOLs

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. A Monofocal Intra-Ocular Lens (IOL) is an artificial lens implanted in the eye that has a single fixed focus , typically set for distance vision , requiring the use of glasses for near tasks .
  • • Option A.
  • • artificial lens
  • • implanted
  • • eye
  • • single fixed focus
  • • distance vision
  • • use
  • • glasses
  • • near tasks
  • • Option B. Accommodative IOLs are advanced artificial lenses designed to move or change shape inside the eye , mimicking the eye's natural ability to change focus ( accommodation ) between distant and near objects .
  • • Option B.
  • • advanced artificial lenses
  • • move
  • • change shape inside
  • • eye
  • • mimicking
  • • eye's natural ability
  • • change focus
  • • accommodation
  • • distant
  • • near objects
  • • Option C. Piggyback IOLs involve the implantation of a second intraocular lens over an existing IOL , usually to correct residual refractive errors such as residual myopia , hyperopia , or astigmatism .
  • • Option C.
  • • implantation
  • • second intraocular lens
  • • existing IOL
  • • correct
  • • residual refractive errors
  • • residual myopia
  • • hyperopia
  • • astigmatism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multifocal IOLs are artificial lenses implanted in the eye that have multiple focus zones built into the lens , allowing for clear vision at various distances , reducing or eliminating the need for glasses .
  • ➤ Multifocal IOLs
  • ➤ artificial lenses
  • ➤ implanted
  • ➤ eye
  • ➤ multiple focus zones
  • ➤ built
  • ➤ lens
  • ➤ allowing
  • ➤ clear vision
  • ➤ distances
  • ➤ reducing
  • ➤ eliminating
  • ➤ need
  • ➤ glasses
  • ➤ Ref : Pg 317/ Theory & Practise of Optics & Refraction/ 4 th Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : Pg 317/ Theory & Practise of Optics & Refraction/ 4 th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 55-year-old male diagnosed with right eye immature cataract was planned for cataract surgery. But there was poor pupillary dilatation. The technique shown in the image for dilating the pupil is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Iris Hooks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sphincterotomy is a surgical procedure to cut the iris sphincter to achieve mechanical mydriasis .
  • • Option A.
  • • surgical procedure
  • • cut
  • • iris sphincter
  • • achieve mechanical mydriasis
  • • Option B. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique in which an ultrasound device is used to emuslsify cataract within the eye .
  • • Option B.
  • • modern cataract surgery technique
  • • ultrasound device
  • • emuslsify cataract
  • • within
  • • eye
  • • Option D. Trabeculectomy is a surgical procedure to treat glaucoma by creating a drainage fistula in the eye's sclera and trabecular meshwork to lower intraocular pressure by allowing aqueous humor to drain into the subconjunctival space bypassing the trabecular meshwork .
  • • Option D.
  • • surgical procedure
  • • treat glaucoma
  • • drainage fistula
  • • eye's sclera
  • • trabecular meshwork
  • • lower intraocular pressure
  • • allowing aqueous humor
  • • drain
  • • subconjunctival space
  • • trabecular meshwork

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iris hooks are small devices used during eye surgery to mechanically dilate the pupil and provide better access and visibility , especially in cases where the pupil does not dilate sufficiently on its own.
  • ➤ Iris hooks
  • ➤ small devices
  • ➤ during eye surgery
  • ➤ mechanically dilate
  • ➤ pupil
  • ➤ better access
  • ➤ visibility
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.aao.org/education/clinical-video/iris-hook-technique
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.aao.org/education/clinical-video/iris-hook-technique

questions.text: Which of the following is derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Structures derived from Surface Ectoderm :
  • • Surface Ectoderm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The surface ectoderm gives rise to crystalline lens , epithelium of cornea and epithelium of conjunctiva .
  • ➤ surface ectoderm
  • ➤ crystalline lens
  • ➤ epithelium
  • ➤ cornea
  • ➤ epithelium
  • ➤ conjunctiva
  • ➤ Ref: Pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6 th Edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6 th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with severe ocular pain and redness accompanied with dimunition in vision and discharge. After extensive examination, he was diagnosed with endophthalmitis. Which is the preferred combination of intravitreal antibiotics you will prescribe for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1mg Vancomycin + 2.25mg Ceftazidime

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 0.1mg Moxifloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic , but it is not commonly used alone as an intravitreal injection for the treatment of endophthalmitis . Monotherapy is generally less favored due to the diverse range of potential infective organisms .
  • • Option A. 0.1mg Moxifloxacin
  • • broad-spectrum antibiotic
  • • intravitreal injection
  • • endophthalmitis
  • • Monotherapy
  • • less favored
  • • diverse range
  • • potential infective organisms
  • • Option C. 1mg Vancomycin + 0.4mg Gentamycin : While this combination provides broad coverage against both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms , the use of Gentamycin has declined due to its potential toxicity , particularly the risk of macular ischaemia .
  • • Option C.
  • • combination
  • • broad coverage
  • • against
  • • gram-positive
  • • gram-negative organisms
  • • Gentamycin
  • • declined
  • • potential toxicity
  • • risk
  • • macular ischaemia
  • • Option D. 2.25mg Ceftazidime + 0.4mg Amikacin : Ceftazidime covers gram-negative bacteria , and Amikacin is another aminoglycoside like Gentamycin . Like Gentamycin, Amikacin has potential toxicities . This combination, while effective , is generally less preferred due to the concerns of macular ischaemia associated with aminoglycosides .
  • • Option D.
  • • gram-negative bacteria
  • • Amikacin
  • • aminoglycoside
  • • Gentamycin
  • • potential toxicities
  • • effective
  • • less preferred
  • • macular ischaemia
  • • aminoglycosides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate and preferred combination for treating endophthalmitis is 1mg Vancomycin + 2.25mg Ceftazidime . This combination is broadly effective against the range of bacteria typically implicated in endophthalmitis and is the standard of care in many clinical settings .
  • ➤ appropriate
  • ➤ preferred combination
  • ➤ endophthalmitis
  • ➤ 1mg Vancomycin + 2.25mg Ceftazidime
  • ➤ broadly effective
  • ➤ against
  • ➤ implicated
  • ➤ endophthalmitis
  • ➤ standard of care
  • ➤ many clinical settings
  • ➤ Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22 nd Edition Page 243
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Parsons Diseases of Eye 22 nd Edition Page 243

questions.text: A patient who underwent an ocular surgery a week back, now complaints of pain, redness, photophobia and decrease in vision. The surgeon suspects post-operative endophthalmitis. Which of the following topical drugs is known to reduce the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5% Povidone Iodine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 1% Azithromycin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic and can be used topically for bacterial infections of the eye. However, it is not the primary agent known for reducing the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis .
  • • Option A. 1% Azithromycin
  • • broad-spectrum antibiotic
  • • topically
  • • bacterial infections
  • • reducing
  • • risk
  • • post-operative endophthalmitis
  • • Option C. 0.5% Moxifloxacin : Moxifloxacin is a fourth-generation fluoroquinolone antibiotic used topically for bacterial infections of the eye. While it is effective against a range of bacteria , its primary use is not specifically for reducing the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis in the same preventive capacity as povidone iodine .
  • • Option C. 0.5% Moxifloxacin
  • • Moxifloxacin
  • • fourth-generation fluoroquinolone antibiotic
  • • topically
  • • bacterial infections
  • • effective against
  • • range
  • • bacteria
  • • risk
  • • post-operative endophthalmitis
  • • same preventive capacity
  • • povidone iodine
  • • Option D. 5% Vancomycin is an antibiotic that can be used to treat serious bacterial infections , including Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) . It's not typically used as a prophylactic measure against post-operative endophthalmitis in a topical form.
  • • Option D. 5% Vancomycin
  • • antibiotic
  • • treat serious bacterial infections
  • • Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most effective and commonly used agent for reducing the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis is 5% Povidone Iodine . This antiseptic solution is applied preoperatively to the ocular surface to minimize the presence of potential infectious agents .
  • ➤ most effective
  • ➤ commonly
  • ➤ reducing
  • ➤ risk
  • ➤ post-operative endophthalmitis
  • ➤ 5% Povidone Iodine
  • ➤ preoperatively
  • ➤ ocular surface
  • ➤ minimize
  • ➤ presence
  • ➤ potential infectious agents
  • ➤ Ref: AAO Section: 2 – 2020 Edition Page 428
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ AAO Section: 2 – 2020 Edition Page 428
